DOC.HEAD: Haitian Cabinet Reshuffle, Change In Army High Command
DOC.TEXT: PORT-AU-PRINCE, Haiti (AP) _ A new Cabinet was sworn in Tuesday after Lt. Gen. Prosper Avril replaced seven ministers, the police chief and a top army officer in the biggest government shakeup since he took power last year. Franck Paultre, the former public works minister, replaced Leonce Thelusma as finance minister in the reshuffle, announced on state-run TV late Monday. Thelusma was criticized for his foreign currency-control policy and for having signed a controversial agreement with the International Monetary Fund. Brig. Gen. Fritz Romulus, the former airport chief who was newly promoted from colonel, replaced Brig. Gen. Acedius Saint-Louis as defense and interior minister. Saint-Louis drew fire as being ineffective in fighting urban gangsterism. Romulus, reputed to be a moderate, is the only military man in the 13-member Cabinet. Serge Petit-Frere replaced Remy Zamor as education minister. Teachers accused Zamor of authoritarianism. They struck several times, protesting they had not been paid. They overwhelmingly rejected an insurance plan Zamor presented for teachers and it was shelved. Also replaced were the ministers of commerce, planning, agriculture and public administration. Col. Henri Robert Augustin, the police chief, was replaced by Lt. Col. Martial Romulus, who was military attache at the Haitian Embassy in Washington. Maj. Gen. Max Valles, one of Haiti's nine generals, was retired. For six weeks in 1986, Valles was a member of the provisional junta which took over after dictator Jean-Claude Duvalier fled into French exile. Avril came to power in a bloodless coup in September 1988 that ousted Lt. Gen. Henri Namphy.
